audio_analysis.transcript: Stop for a second. The video you were watching was pretty funny, right? And now that I interrupted it, it bothered you. Didn't it? Look at this. This is your face. And you don't look that happy. You probably didn't even care about that video. So why did you want to keep watching it? Something interesting is happening in your brain, a chemical explosion of dopamine. That's the substance your brain releases when you watch videos like that. And there's a problem. It's addictive. Exactly. I'm not going to put that video because you liked it, but because your brain needs more dopamine. Probably only 10% of people have made it this far into the video. Because all this need for dopamine has consequences, especially on our attention. Have you noticed that you can't focus on a book, watch a movie, or study without grabbing your phone? That's brain rock. It's the loss of your cognitive abilities, like attention and memory, caused by excessive consumption of quick, useless content. And the saddest part is, we're all victims of this phenomenon. Let's do a test. Watch this video. I'm looking at my phone. What is this? I mean, that's why it says, you. Ah! Now, close your eyes for a moment. Feel what's happening in your body. If you pay close attention, your hand is probably already ready to scroll for another video. Your brain is looking for that pleasure feeling that comes with another dose of dopamine. And if you don't see anything wrong with all of this, you should know that these chemical reactions in your brain are affecting your daily life. Not only are your attention levels dropping, but so is your intelligence. Think for a second. When you scroll on social media, your brain shuts off. It's not thinking about anything. It's receiving millions of useless stimuli that just make it more tired. If you keep this up, you'll lose your creativity, your reasoning ability, and your memory. This legal drug is corroding your brain, making you dumber. And the real question is, is this really what you want? Probably not. So how can you avoid brain rock? Awareness is the first step. Picking up your phone, ask yourself, do I really need this? Or will I spend the next two hours trapped in the screen watching pointless things? You won't be able to control this impulse right away. But as soon as you finish using your phone, take a deep breath and ask yourself, do I feel better or worse than before? The second step is action. Remove all the apps that make you addicted to your phone and use them from your computer. Or by accessing them through a search engine. Turn off notifications for all apps that aren't important. Put your phone in black and white mode. Turn on, do not disturb. And leave it in another room while you work or before going to bed. The worst thing you can do is use your phone right after waking up. These are small things that will help you escape from this trap we've gotten so used to. And that seems normal to use so much. So if you really want to stop wasting time and escape brain rock, leave YouTube and apply the tips I just gave you before you forget them. Good luck. It's for your own good.
